trial_identification.studytitle: An observational study in patients undergoing mechanical ventilation to assess the influence of the adjustments made in the artificial ventilation on the agreement level of pulmonary auscultation (The Kappa analysis)
trial_identification.scientifictitle: An observational study in patients undergoing mechanical ventilation to assess the influence of the adjustments made in the artificial ventilation on the agreement level of pulmonary auscultation (The Kappa analysis)

conditions.healthcondition: The study was developed with the intention of evaluating the influence of the adjustments made in the artificial ventilation in the intraobserver and interobserver agreement of pulmonary auscultation in patients submitted to artificial ventilation.

interventions.interventions: Methods: twenty-three patients submitted to artificial ventilation were investigated in the Intensive Care Unit. Three Respiratory Physiotherapists performed the auscultation at three distinct times , regarding the ventilator adjustment (tidal volume 8ml/k8 and 20ml/kg and flow 40l/mim and 80l/mim ), however in a row in the same moment.

primaryOutcome.outcome: The interobserver agreement at the best moment of adjustment of the artificial ventilation presented kappa = 0.65 for rhonchi, 0.59 for fine crackles, 0.57 for coarse crackles and 0.36 for bronchial sound.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: The intraobserver agreement level, at the best moment, presented kappa average of 0.62 for rhonchi, 0.82 for coarse crackles, 0.54 for bronchial sound and 0.39 for fine crackles.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Older than 18, undergo mechanical ventilation, positive end expiratory pressure (PEEP) level in mechanical ventilation <6cmH2O

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Pulmonary auscultation is a important assessment tool in respiratory care. To assess the level of agreement is necessery. The hypothesis is that the way that the ventilator is setting can interfere in the result.
